text:
I’m a Master of Business Analytics student at Monash University. Previously, have worked as a business development professional who turns data, customer insight, and disciplined execution into growth. I’ve led sales teams, built repeatable go-to-market playbooks, and improved retention through tighter customer relationships and smarter use of analytics.
Right now I’m focused on sharpening my Business Analytics & Data Science toolkit so I can take strategy from slideware to measurable outcomes: cleaner pipelines, faster feedback loops, and dashboards that leaders actually use. I enjoy translating messy signals (CRM, ops, finance) into simple decisions the team can rally behind.
Previously I led a 15-person sales team with a strong culture of self-drive and accountability, built planning cadences that lifted revenue and share, and deepened key-account relationships through upsell and service add-ons. Before that, I ran day-to-day operations—shipping/receiving, inventory control, and transport—tracking KPIs, fixing bottlenecks with cross-functional partners, and coaching teams to higher productivity.
I’m most at home where customers, numbers, and narrative meet: give me a target, a dataset and I’ll ship something I’m proud of on time.
Skills & interests: sales strategy, account growth, CRM optimisation, business intelligence, team coaching, data storytelling with R/Quarto/GitHub.
Education: B.Tech (Mechanical Engineering), UIET—MD University, India.

title: How Much Did Climate Change Raise Australia’s 2019/20 Bushfire Risk?
text:
The 2019/20 “Black Summer” bushfires were historically severe. How much did anthropogenic climate change increase the likelihood of the risk factors that drove that season—extreme heat, drought, and fire weather? And what does that imply for future seasons?
Note - This post adapts results from van Oldenborgh et al. (2021) and supporting sources.

title: How Much Did Climate Change Raise Australia’s 2019/20 Bushfire Risk?
text:
The 2019/20 “Black Summer” bushfires were historically severe. How much did anthropogenic climate change increase the likelihood of the risk factors that drove that season—extreme heat, drought, and fire weather? And what does that imply for future seasons?
Note - This post adapts results from van Oldenborgh et al. (2021) and supporting sources.

title: How Much Did Climate Change Raise Australia’s 2019/20 Bushfire Risk?
text:
Analysis

Data & sources

Attribution study: van Oldenborgh et al. (2021), NHESS — observational records, reanalyses, and multiple model ensembles to estimate probability ratios (PR) for extremes under today’s vs pre-industrial climate [@oldenborgh2021].

Context: IPCC AR6 WGI (2021) [@ipcc2021] and CSIRO/BOM State of the Climate (2020) [@csiro2020].



Findings (heat, drought, fire weather)

Extreme heat: events like Dec-2019 are ≥2× as likely due to warming; long records suggest up to ~10× increase.

Drought: attribution inconclusive for 2019—the IOD and SAM dominated that year’s rainfall deficits.

Fire weather (FWI / MSR): extremes are roughly 4–9× more likely now than in early 20th century; models tend to underestimate the observed increase.

To visualize these reported ranges, we encode a simple dataset (min/central/max PR) and draw a range plot. The figure is a communication aid (not a new estimate).








Figure 1: Probability ratios (PR) for Black Summer drivers with uncertainty. The light band marks ‘no clear change’ around PR≈1; values to the right indicate higher likelihood in today’s climate.





As Figure 1 shows, heat and fire weather push well above PR = 1 (more likely now), while drought hovers near ~1 (no robust detection for 2019).


Models used in the attribution study
The original study uses several large ensembles across CMIP generations and attribution projects. Table 1 lists a small subset to show the diversity of models

Why it matters. A multi-model approach reduces dependence on any single model. Notably, @oldenborgh2021 report that models likely understate the observed rise in fire weather, so real-world risk may be higher than central model estimates.

title: How Much Did Climate Change Raise Australia’s 2019/20 Bushfire Risk?
text:
Conclusion
Climate change materially increased the likelihood of the heat and fire-weather extremes that drove Black Summer, while drought attribution for 2019 remained inconclusive due to strong natural modes (IOD/SAM). This aligns with @oldenborgh2021 and the broader assessments in @ipcc2021 and @csiro2020.
So we expect more frequent severe fire seasons under further warming; treat modelled fire-weather increases as possibly conservative (models understate observed trends). Priorities: infrastructure hardening, emergency capacity, land-use planning—and mitigation to limit future risk.
For planners and emergency services, treat modelled fire-weather increases as conservative, and prioritise infrastructure hardening, response capacity, land-use planning, and emissions mitigation.
